bridge-story.text: The Gap Nobody Mentions. Here's a secret your professors won't tell you: the gap between classroom CS and industry engineering is massive. But it doesn't have to be. Your academic foundation is solid — you just need a translation layer.

What You've Learned. Think about what you've built: algorithms, data structures, database theory, software design principles. This isn't just academic exercise — it's the foundation that industry builds on.

This Course Is The Bridge. This course connects what you know to how software is actually built. Design patterns, modern tools, AI-augmented development. Same concepts you learned, applied to real production systems.
Industry-Ready. The destination: internships, full-time roles, career growth. You're not starting from zero — you're translating knowledge you already have into the language industry speaks.

Your Knowledge Transfers. That binary search tree you implemented? Industry uses self-balancing variants like Red-Black trees. The concept is identical — your knowledge transfers. You just need to see the connection.

translation-story.text: Same Concepts, Different Names. Everything you learned in class maps to something in industry. Linked lists and arrays become choosing the right data store. Big-O analysis becomes performance optimization at scale.
Theory to Practice. Database normalization becomes schema design for real products. UML diagrams become architecture documentation. Software design principles become code review standards.

The Hash Table Example. In class, you implement a hash table from scratch with collision handling. In industry, you use Python's built-in dict or Redis for distributed caching. Same concept, production-ready tools.
The Key Insight. Here's the insight: you learned the fundamentals so you can understand and debug the abstractions. Interviewers test the fundamentals. Industry uses the abstractions. You need both.

patterns-story.text: Patterns Everywhere. Certain patterns appear in every production codebase. Learn them once, recognize them everywhere. They're the shared vocabulary of professional software engineering.

Repository Pattern. The Repository Pattern abstracts data access. Your code doesn't care if it's SQL, NoSQL, or an API. You define an interface, then swap implementations without changing business logic.
Factory Pattern. The Factory Pattern creates objects without exposing creation logic. Seen in every framework — React components, Django models, Spring beans. It keeps code flexible and testable.
Dependency Injection. Dependency Injection means passing dependencies in, not creating them internally. This is what enables testing — inject a mock database instead of hitting production!

The SOLID Connection. Remember Liskov Substitution from OOP class? That's exactly what makes Repository Pattern work — any implementation can be swapped in. Your academic knowledge is the foundation for industry patterns!
